p: Influenza is an important contributor to morbidity and mortality in Africa [ 1]. Among 15 countries of the African Network for Influenza Surveillance and Epidemiology (ANISE), 10% and 22% of inpatient and outpatient respiratory cases, respectively, tested positive for influenza between 2006â€“2010 [ 2]. For many years, influenza epidemiology has been described in countries with temperate climates like South Africa and Morocco [ 3, 4] but there are now data that comprehensively describe influenza viruses in tropical countries like Kenya and Zambia [ 5, 6]. In Africa, influenza causes severe illness and deaths in both temperate and tropical settings [ 7, 8].
